page.title: 08FARMING: MILK PRODUCTION
page.content: Two Friesian milking herds graze in our area. Both have about 130 animals, about 55 to 75 of which are "in milk". The rest are "followers" - replacement heifers (this year's and last year's calves, plus in-calf heifers). They are either put to the bull or artificially inseminated (by "the bull in the bowler hat") at just under two years old, calving at two and three- quarters. Neither farm rears beef, so all steer calves are sold. One farm has an autumn calving so its peak milking period is in winter, when milk prices are highest. Milk fetches perhaps 12p per litre in summer up to 15p or 17p in winter (prices also vary with the quality of the milk). Each herd can produce 1,000 to 1,200 litres a day. A cow gives 5,000-6,000 litres a year, and eats about a tonne of cattle cake, in addition to grass.
